response.answer_text: How important is perfection?   Well, it may depend upon what you do for your livliehood — where perfection is not only admirable but necessary to save or preserve lives. If you’re piloting an aircraft, perfection is 99% important, as is the performance of the air traffic controller in the tower bringing you in safely to land, and ground control getting you to the gate safely. If you’re an emergency medical responder — again, perfection is 99% important. Judge, professor, lawyer, paralegal, social worker, medical doctor, nurse, psychiatrist, psychologist, veterinarian, animal health technician, IT specialist, computer programmer, actor, movie producer, plumber, electrician, carpenter, engineer, scientist, astronaut, astronomer, bank teller, financial advisor, et el — well … I suggest all require 99% perfection. I apologize to those I’ve missed. Perhaps, if you’re a public schoolteacher, you might get away with 80% -90% perfection. However, a bartender or a waitress — wow …that really might matter to be perhaps 95%perfect — otherwise you might not get excellent tips if you far below perfect. A janitor, shelf restocker, non-cashier worker in a random store, salesperson for cell phones,Life Insurance or pharmaceuticals … probably the bar is set lower. Salespeople sell … perfection is perhaps then like horseshoes and hand grenades … close to perfection IS good enough.

How important is perfection? Not at all. Perfection is just a step-back and-appreciate-value judgment that lets you know: Not one single flaw here. Wouldn’t change a thing. This is perfect. Now, it might be a nice thing to be attuned to that. To be able to notice: where things come together, and you and me are just perfect for this moment, and for each other, and it’s all just perfect for us. That kind of stuff is nice to notice. But it doesn’t change a single actual thing about the thing, the person, the moment. It doesn’t change a thing about what IS, what actually IS, just to notice what’s missing: A flaw. Or flaws. So it’s not really important at all. It’s a judgment that adds zilch to the actual good of what’s there. But some people, you know, they’ve got a perfectionism fetish so it means a lot to them. They wanna notice some, then they notice so hard they start to import fake flaws to make the chase more exciting next time. Yeah, it’s really not important.  Remember: perfection pertains to purpose. There is no perfect, except perfect for. If you’re looking for perfection, make sure you know what - whatever it is - is supposed to be perfect for.

Perfection is the Ideal End Goal of creation. It is the Reward of the continuous striving efforts to improve. The striving to improve is the inherent quality of our spirit nature given to us by our creator God. It is a fundamental quality of mind of all living things and beings. To adapt, evolve, learn, improve, grow, advance, are all qualities of dynamic “living” things. Stagnation, or failure in any of these areas will eventually lead to the “death” of that living thing. To find out more, go to The Harps of God and read “The Urantia Book”.
Perfection is a great thing. It takes a lot of time. So go for it only in case of very important things on a very selective basis. For the rest, save time and be happy with a moderate perfection.
You can't make a mirror by polishing a brick. You can't make a silk purse out of a sow's ear. Laurence Mather's answer to Does the happiness in your life depend upon the quality of your thoughts?
